perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees to hold in confidence confidential information acquired in the course of this relationship with the other Parties and their associates. Each Party agrees to refrain from, either during period of this Agreement or at any other time thereafter, disclosing, using or disseminating such confidential information, for its or another's benefit, in any way acquired in the course of any association arising out of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party will endeavor to hold in confidence confidential information acquired during this relationship. Each Party will try to refrain from disclosing confidential information, acquired during this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'agrees to hold in confidence' and 'agrees to refrain from' are replaced with 'will endeavor to hold in confidence' and 'will try to refrain from', weakening the obligation to maintain confidentiality. This introduces ambiguity as 'endeavor' and 'try' suggest effort rather than a strict requirement, potentially allowing parties to disclose confidential information if they deem it necessary.
perturbation.law_explanation: PUTSA, as adopted in Pennsylvania, provides legal remedies for the misappropriation of trade secrets. By weakening the confidentiality obligation, the modified text makes it more difficult to prove misappropriation, as the duty to protect confidential information is no longer strictly defined, potentially conflicting with the statute's intent to protect trade secrets.

perturbation.original_text: Venue for any action brought under this Agreement shall be in the appropriate court in Mercer County, Pennsylvania.
perturbation.changed_text: Venue for any action related to this Agreement may preferably be in a court located in Mercer County, Pennsylvania.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall be' to 'may preferably be' introduces ambiguity regarding the mandatory nature of the venue. The original text clearly dictates that any legal action must occur in Mercer County, PA. The modified text suggests a preference, but does not explicitly require it, potentially allowing lawsuits to be filed elsewhere.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 1006
perturbation.law_explanation: Pa.R.C.P. 1006 outlines the rules for venue in Pennsylvania. While parties can agree to a specific venue, the modified text's ambiguity could lead to disputes over whether the agreement is enforceable, conflicting with the principle of contractual certainty and potentially leading to litigation outside the agreed-upon jurisdiction if a court finds the clause non-binding.

perturbation.original_text: THI shall prepay Marv for any affirmed IP Cost before payment is to be made by Marv. Marv shall have no duty to pay an IP Cost, whether affirmed or not affirmed, for which Marv does not receive prepayment.
perturbation.changed_text: THI should prepay Marv for affirmed IP Costs when feasible before Marv makes the payment. Marv will generally not be expected to pay an IP Cost if Marv does not receive prepayment.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall' to 'should when feasible' and 'shall have no duty' to 'will generally not be expected' introduces ambiguity. 'Should when feasible' makes prepayment discretionary and subject to interpretation, while 'generally not be expected' does not entirely remove Marv's obligation to pay. This ambiguity weakens the financial obligations of THI and creates potential disputes over IP cost payments.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract Laws in Pennsylvania
perturbation.law_citation: Pennsylvania law on contracts (no specific section - principles apply)
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania contract law requires clear and definite terms for an agreement to be enforceable. The introduction of ambiguity regarding prepayment of IP costs could render this section of the contract unenforceable, because the terms are not clear, creating uncertainty and hindering the enforcement of the contractual obligation to reimburse Marv for IP costs. This uncertainty undermines the foundational principles of contract law in Pennsylvania.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: CACI No. 303. Breach of Contract - Essential Factual Elements :: California Civil Jury Instructions (CACI) (2025) :: Justia CACI No. 303. Breach of Contract - Essential Factual Elements Judicial Council of California Civil Jury Instructions (2025 edition) Download PDF 303 . Breach of Contract - Essential Factual Elements T o recover damages from [ name of defendant ] for br each of contract, [ name of plaintiff ] must prove all of the following: 1. That [ name of plaintiff ] and [ name of defendant ] entered into a contract; [2. That [ name of plaintiff ] did all, or substantially all, of the significant things that the contract required [him/her/ nonbinary pronoun /it] to do;] [2. [or] [2. That [ name of plaintiff ] was excused from having to [ specify things that plaintiff did not do, e.g., obtain a guarantor on the contract ];] [3. That [ specify occurrence of all conditions required by the contract for [name of defendant]’s performance, e.g., the property was rezoned for residential use ];] [3. [or] [3. That [ specify condition(s) that did not occur ] [was/were] [waived/ excused];] [4. That [ name of defendant ] failed to do something that the contract required [him/her/ nonbinary pronoun /it] to do;] [4. [ or ] [4. That [ name of defendant ] did something that the contract prohibited [him/her/ nonbinary pronoun /it] from doing;] 5. That [ name of plaintiff ] was harmed; and 6. That [ name of defendant ]’s breach of contract was a substantial factor in causing [ name of plaintiff ]’s harm. New September 2003; Revised April 2004, June 2006, December 2010, June 201 1, June 2013, June 2015, December 2016, May 2020 Directions for Use Read this instruction in conjunction with CACI No. 300, Br each of Contract - Intr oduction . Optional elements 2 and 3 both involve conditions precedent. A “condition precedent” is either an act of a party that must be performed or an uncertain event that must happen before the contractual right accrues or the contractual duty arises. ( Stephens & Stephens XII, LLC v . Fireman’ s Fund Ins. Co. (2014) 231 Cal.App.4th 91 1 131, 1 147 [180 Cal.Rptr .3d 683].) Element 2 involves the first kind of condition precedent; an act that must be performed by one party before the other is required to perform. Include the second option if the plaintif f alleges that the plaintif f was excused from having to perform some or all of the contractual conditions. Not every breach of contract by the plaintif f will relieve the defendant of the obligation to perform. The breach must be material; element 2 captures materiality by requiring that the plaintif f have done the significant things that the contract required. Also, the two obligations must be dependent , meaning that the parties specifically bargained that the failure to perform the one relieves the obligation to perform the other . While materiality is generally a question of fact, whether covenants are dependent or independent is a matter of construing the agreement. ( Br own v . Grimes (201 1) 192 Cal.App.4th 265, 277-279 [120 Cal.Rptr .3d 893].) If there is no extrinsic evidence in aid of construction, the question is one of law for the court. ( V er dier v . V erdier (1955) 133 Cal.App.2d 325, 333 [284 P .2d 94].) Therefore, element 2 should not be given unless the court has determined that dependent obligations are involved. If parol evidence is required and a dispute of facts is presented, additional instructions on the disputed facts will be necessary . (See City of Hope National Medical Center v . Genentech, Inc. (2008) 43 Cal.4th 375, 395 [75 Cal.Rptr .3d 333, 181 P .3d 142].) Element 3 involves the second kind of condition precedent; an uncertain event that must happen before contractual duties are triggered. Include the second option if the plaintif f alleges that the defendant agreed to perform even though a condition did not occur . For reasons that the occurrence of a condition may have been excused, see the Restatement Second of Contracts, sect
